item.title: Comment on *Is Inequality the Problem?* by Hazel Meade
item.description:
The countries with the truly highest levels of inequality tend to be extremely poor, not rich, and the reason for that is political corruption - a tiny rich elite controls the government, owns everything, and everyone else has no enforceable rights, and hence no legal property, and thus no wealth.

It's not that inequality reduces longevity, but that extreme inequality tends to be coupled with extreme poverty.

item.title: Comment on Monday assorted links by Kevin Postlewaite
item.description:
5. When I read summary points in the post like "That Trump's election victory means the final defeat of modern progressive liberalism (or hyper-liberalism as he has it)." I feel like that ascribes too much intentionality and too much permanence to a presidential vote. Thinking back 40-80 years, would it have been correct to chalk up particular presidential votes to everlasting supremacy of one ideology over another? Did any past vote indicate the ascendancy of liberalism, and this vote a dfinitive repudiation of liberalism?

It's akin to a weather report saying "Today's unseasonably warm weather means that winter will never come again!"
